text: St Andrew's Church, Wolverhampton is a parish church in the Church of England in WolverhamptonThe Buildings of England. Staffordshire. Nikolaus Pevsner. Penguin Books. p.324 ==History== The foundation stone of St Andrew's was laid by Revd. J.H. Iles on 25 May 1865 and building started to the designs of local architect Edward Banks. It was to have enough room for 311 persons. The church was extended in 1870 with space for 700 seats and consecrated on 2 November 1870. The church was added to in 1891 and 1892 by F.T. Beck. On 31 May 1964 it was destroyed by fire. The new church was designed by Richard Twentyman and construction started in 1965 and the church was opened in 1967. The west window was designed by John Piper and created by Patrick Reyntiens. The church cost £48,000 (equivalent to £ in ). Pevsner described the building as Blocky, of brick, and convincing. ==References== Category:Church of England church buildings in the West Midlands (county) Category:Rebuilt churches in the United Kingdom Category:Churches completed in 1967 Category:20th-century Church of England church buildings
